author: donschoe
content:
Does anyone have an opinion on simplifying the genesis time formula?

https://github.com/ethereum/eth2.0-specs/issues/1849

author: jgm
content:
I'm broadly of the same opinion as you, although I have a slightly higher preference for option 0 for marketing reasons (gives us more time between genesis being defined and  chainstart to get the word out, gives us a "well-known" time for genesis).

And I'd hope we aren't going to go through too many more testnet restarts (<10?) before we have a long-lived multi-client testnet and don't have to worry about it on a day-to-day basis.

author: mpetrunic
content: I'm also in favor of option 2 makes much more sense for setting local dev networks since you can set delay to 0 for network to start whenever you have enough validators

author: nishant0
content: Wouldnt that be the same as we have now, if we set the genesis delay to zero ? It would also start immediately

author: nishant0
content: I would favour 0 just for the reason that it would be best to avoid any breaking changes except for critical bug fixes now, but 2 is fine too if everyone else wants to go in that direction

author: handelaar2
content:
> Hash slinging slasher
<@!118185622543269890> I guess it is too late to add graffiti to the slashing messages? It could bring some recognition for the people stupid enough to run a slasher. And it would help with testing. ü§ì

author: donschoe
content: ~~Having a delay of `0` is basically Option 2 üôÇ~~ Edit, I wasn't thinking.

author: donschoe
content: The problem with a delay of `0` is that we don't test with mainnet constants and let me remind you that the first Witti attempt failed due to differently computed genesis times.

author: kiwi.eth
content: <@!219523277163331586> the only slashings that could have graffiti are proposal slashings really

content: for attestations, might be a bit more complicated, my first slashing on witti had the beaconblockroot of "oh god oh fuck" lol

author: protolambda
content: It is, but all clients would need to adopt it, people need to agree on it, etc.

author: kiwi.eth
content: Ahh yeah that would be pretty simple, I misunderstood

author: kiwi.eth
content: Thing is, in that example, that graffiti would be set by the person (node? slasher?) creating the slashing

author: kiwi.eth
content: Not by the person committing it

author: handelaar2
content: > Yeah, --graffiti  parameter in the slasher, like we already have in the  validator.

author: kiwi.eth
content: And anyone could just change the graffiti, and face no penalties

author: handelaar2
content: understood. But now we have nothing to test this. And it would be an incentive for people running a slasher (to set their mark)

author: kiwi.eth
content: Thats a good point

author: kiwi.eth
content: Considering theyre just broadcasted

author: kiwi.eth
content: And we cant know from who theyre from

author: kiwi.eth
content: Theres actually a whistleblower reward as part of the spec

author: handelaar2
content: exactly, with that, we can. And if people dont want to populate,. they leave it blank

author: kiwi.eth
content: But no one has really implemented it since it can be removed with no penalty, and it takes a share of the slashing reward

author: protolambda
content: We could implement it differently: someone creates some API endpoint, and a slasher sends the hash-tree-root (unique unpredictable hash) of the slashable event to the API. The first sender is the original performer who discovered the slashing, and gets a spot on a leaderboard or something.

author: handelaar2
content: Some sort of (at least non-monetary) incentive would be good as running a slasher is not easy.

author: protolambda
content: And then we simply collect the slashings that get on chain, compare their roots against those collected in the API, and we have a leaderboard of slashers üôÇ

author: jgm
content: Yeah, some sort of off-chain solution to this would be best.

author: protolambda
content: Things like this are a good first step towards incentivised testnets

author: kiwi.eth
content: Tagging <@!97774605351010304> for potential brainstorms

author: protolambda
content: And off-chain is opt-in and doesn't cause protocol friction for client implementers

author: protolambda
content: I might just implement this leaderboard thing this weekend, sounds fun

author: kiwi.eth
content: I'm still confused as to why the whistleblower reward is still in the spec, slashings have no indication of who they're from when broadcasted no?

author: protolambda
content: And another related thing I'm working on is E2DB, to collect and index testnet events, to build APIs and other stuff like this

author: protolambda
content: Whistleblower reward is for later use in phase 1

author: protolambda
content: So we can re-use the same functionality

author: kiwi.eth
content: Right, just not sure why it wasn't moved to phase 1 spec like most other things

author: protolambda
content: In phase0 there is not really a neat trustless way to reward the slashing finder. Only the proposer who mines the event. Unfortunately

author: djrtwo
content: a slasher finder can hoard the slashing for their own proposals but then (1) don't help the network as quickly and (2) might very well just get passed up anyway

cc <@!361447803194441738>  <@!498009160982724610>

author: protolambda
content: <@!343424945914904577> the deposit may take a while to get acknowledged in eth1 data, processed, and queued. I'll try and check what happened to yours

author: protolambda
content: <@!343424945914904577> My deposit processing script says the deposit is invalid, but you end up as validator 620. While currently only 579 validators are processed and known in the state. There's either an Eth1 voting  backlog, or an unprocessed deposit queue

author: liangcc.eth
content: Thanks <@!203220829473996800> . I noticed that while some client packed a 4hrs ago eth1 blocks , some are still packing the 8~9 hours ago eth1 blocks.

author: liangcc.eth
content: Ah interesting, I'll wait and check. Thank you so much

author: protolambda
content: Was planning to do some large deposit rounds myself today, but if there's already a queue I might need to hold off

author: protolambda
content: One of the reasons why I prefer a larger genesis, is that the queue and voting is less of a problem, making participation easier

author: jgm

author: protolambda
content: <@!97774605351010304> I'm considering changing it to register claims with an eth1 contract later. But let's  start simple

author: protolambda
content: We could have an eth2stats-like client, which calls APIs to get some performance data, learn about slasher findings, etc., and then submits it to the API. And later maybe register some of it through an Eth1 transaction to a smart contract

author: protolambda
content: And once the claim can be verified, the first one to claim gets a plus on the leaderboard/token/whatever

author: protolambda
content: Mostly I'm just looking to experiment with incentives, and only then organize/grow it bigger.

author: hsiaowei
content:
<@!203220829473996800> 
> the deposit is invalid, but you end up as validator 620. While currently only 579 validators are processed and known in the state.
How can an invalid deposit registers a new validator? Do you mean `eth1_deposit_index` = 620?

author: protolambda
content: the deposit index is likely already higher, given that there may be topups and bad signature deposits. What I got was that the deposit of CC, after processing the earlier deposits, resulted in that validator index. But it will take some time for the eth1 data to be voted in, so that the deposit actually happens, and the actual validator is created in the beacon state.

author: protolambda
content: Sneak peek of new tooling, and why it took so long for the first Witti validator deposit to get acknowledged. A 50% vote made it, but there was contention!

author: terence0083
content: From Prysm side, we haven't looked at proposer's eth1 voting routine seriously since 0.9 or even earlier

author: protolambda
content: Also indexing all of the other beacon state components, and working to optimize + keep watching live for data. It's like an explorer, except I can run queries for debugging this kind of stuff.

author: protolambda
content: <@!363800010518822915> No problem, see if there's some obvious difference and try to fix, or we may be able to figure it out from a deeper look into the voting data
